abstract.text: The central object for managing notification-related activities for your app or app extension.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: object to manage all notification-related behaviors in your app or app extension. Specifically, use this object to do the following:
Request authorization to interact with the user through alerts, sounds, and icon badges. See
Declare the notification types that your app supports and the custom actions the user may perform when the system delivers those notifications. See
Schedule the delivery of notifications from your app. See
Process the payloads from remote notifications the system delivers by Apple Push Notification service (APNs). See
Manage the already delivered notifications the system displays in Notification Center. See Managing Delivered Notifications.
Handle user-selected actions associated with your custom notification types. See
Get the notification-related settings for your app. See Managing Settings and Authorization.
To handle incoming notifications and notification-related actions, create an object that adopts the
protocol and assign it to the
property. Always assign an object to the
property before performing any tasks that might interact with that delegate.
You may use the shared user notification center object simultaneously from any of your app’s threads. The object processes requests serially in the order that the system initiates them.

UserNotifications-PageImage-card.png.alt: [A notification interface displayed on the lock screen of an iOS device.]

abstract.text: Push user-facing notifications to the user’s device from a server, or generate them locally from your app.
Options that determine the authorized features of local and remote notifications.
An object that represents a notification error.
Constants that identify notification errors.
The error domain for notifications.
The object for managing notification-related settings and the authorization status of your app.
The central object for managing notification-related activities for your app or app extension.
Schedules the delivery of a local notification.
Returns your app’s notification center.
The notification center’s delegate.
Fetches all of your app’s delivered notifications that are still present in Notification Center.
Fetches your app’s registered notification categories.
Retrieves the authorization and feature-related settings for your app.
Fetches all of your app’s local notifications that are pending delivery.
Removes all of your app’s delivered notifications from Notification Center.
Removes all of your app’s pending local notifications.
Removes your app’s notifications from Notification Center that match the specified identifiers.
Removes your app’s local notifications that are pending and match the specified identifiers.
Requests a person’s authorization to allow local and remote notifications for your app.
Updates the badge count for your app’s icon.
Registers the notification categories that your app supports.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the device supports notification content extensions.
An interface for processing incoming notifications and responding to notification actions.
Request permission to display alerts, play sounds, or badge the app’s icon in response to a notification.
Differentiate your notifications and add action buttons to the notification interface.
Respond to user interactions with the system’s notification interfaces, including handling your app’s custom actions.
Create and schedule notifications from your app when you want to get the user’s attention.

doc://com.apple.usernotifications/docume.title: Scheduling a notification locally from your app

abstract.text: The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
